title: If you double the diameter of a circle, what happens to the area? - Quora

response.answer_text: Doubling the diameter is effectively doubling the radius; r = ½(diameter). Area of a circle is a function of square of the radius. f(r) = πr² When radius is doubled; f(2r) = π(2r)² = 4πr²; area increases four times. When radius is trebled; f(3r) = π(3r)² = 9πr²; area increases nine times. When radius increases n times; f(nr) = π(nr)² = n²πr²

My dear friend Subash Yadav, We have given that only one condition if “I double the diameter of a circle “. Find out the changed Area =? Now suppose that we have a circle of center C having origin O and radius r and diameter d. Then, Area of the circle will be A = πr^2————(1) Now the area has been shown in radius term we can convert it into the diameter terms. Then A1 = π(d/2)^2 {r= d/2} A1= (π/4)(d^2)————-(2) Now when the diameter will be double then diameter = 2d Now Area A2 = (π/4)[2d]^2= πd^2= A1/4 When you will be double the diameter then the New Area will become (1/4) times of the intial area.
